merge_resolver_example.scenario: User provides PR #123 which has merge conflicts between a bugfix branch and a feature branch that refactored the same code.

step.description: Parse PR number and fetch PR information
step.analysis: The PR is a bugfix for a memory leak issue. This context will help prioritize preserving the fix during conflict resolution.

step.description: Checkout PR branch and prepare for rebase
step.expected_output: Switched to branch 'fix/memory-leak' Your branch is up to date with 'origin/fix/memory-leak'.

Fix memory leak in data processor Resolve all conflicts manually, mark them as resolved with "git add/rm <conflicted_files>", then run "git rebase --continue".

step.analysis: Two files have conflicts: the main processor file and its test file. Both need to be resolved before continuing the rebase.

key_takeaways.takeaway: Always checkout PR with --force and rebase to reveal conflicts
Fetch PR context to understand the intent of changes
Use git blame and commit messages to understand the history
Use GIT_EDITOR=true to ensure non-interactive rebase operations
Complete the rebase process with GIT_EDITOR=true git rebase --continue
Validate that both sets of changes work together
